ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about eastern European intellectual history and some research/writing techniques including writing book reviews for different audiences.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I loved the concept of the course but I think in order to really learn how to be better writers, we needed more opportunities to write and workshop our writing. Even drafting an intro scene, or an op-ed, or rewriting the opening lines of a book we read, and then sharing and getting feedback, would have been so fun and helpful. As is, the class goal is supposed to teach us how to be more creative academic writers, but just reading books (some of which we all agreed were quite badly written) wasn't particularly helpful.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely. Prof. Shore is the best instructor at the Department of History.

Unless the student is specifically interested in (mostly eastern) European intellectual history, then this course is not going to offer the level of broad usefulness its description claims. I did appreciate learning how to write book reviews for different audiences--that was probably the biggest take away for me.
